questions.text: A 78-year-old man was admitted to the hospital 3 days earlier with a suspected pathologic fracture of the right femur. Today he became acutely short of breath. Current vital signs include a heart rate of 115 beats/min, blood pressure of 92/70 mm Hg, and respiratory rate of 32/min. Oxygen saturation is 94% on 4 L of oxygen via nasal cannula. He is anxious and tachypneic, but lung sounds are clear and symmetric. The heart rhythm is regular and no murmurs are appreciated. What is the likely cause of dyspnea
In continuation with previous clinical vignette what will be next step of management

options.label: B
options.text: Immediately administer therapeutic dose of intravenous heparin

options.label: D
options.text: Order a ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) scan of the chest.

questions.correct_answer: B. Immediately administer therapeutic dose of intravenous heparin

questions.text: You received a call from nursing staff for cardiopulmonary arrest of a 72-year-old woman in the intensive care unit. She has no palpable pulse, but the cardiac monitor shows sinus tachycardia at 124/min. Breath sounds are symmetric with bag-mask positive-pressure ventilation. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate administration of high-volume normal saline

questions.correct_answer: C. Immediate administration of high-volume normal saline

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room because of sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. Her symptoms began 1 hour back while she was eating breakfast. A stat non-contrast CT scan of the head is normal. Labs are normal. Physical examination reveals dense hemiplegia of the Right upper and lower extremities. What is the best next step in management of this patient?

An 84-year-old woman develops confusion and agitation after surgery for hip fracture. Her current medications include intravenous fentanyl for pain control, lorazepam for control of her agitation, and deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis. She has also been started on ciprofloxacin for pyuria (culture pending). In addition to frequent reorientation of the patient, which of the following series of actions would best manage this patient’s delirium?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase lorazepam to more effective dose, repeat urinalysis.

options.label: B
options.text: Discontinue lorazepam, remove Foley catheter, add haloperidol for severe agitation, and change to non-fluoroquinolone antibiotic.

options.label: C
options.text: Continue lorazepam at current dose, discontinue fentanyl, and add soft restraints

options.label: D
options.text: Continue lorazepam at current dose, add alprazolam 0.25 mg for severe agitation, repeat urinalysis, and restrain patient to prevent self-harm..

questions.correct_answer: B. Discontinue lorazepam, remove Foley catheter, add haloperidol for severe agitation, and change to non-fluoroquinolone antibiotic.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man admitted to the hospital with an exacerbation of congestive heart failure. Before admission he was able to ambulate two blocks before stopping because of dyspnea. He has now returned to baseline and is ready for discharge. His preadmission medications include aspirin, metoprolol, and furosemide. Systolic blood pressure has ranged from 110 to 128 mm Hg over the course of his hospitalization. Heart rate was in 120 s at the time of presentation, but has been consistently around 70/min over the past 24 hours. An echocardiogram performed during this hospitalization revealed global hypokinesis with an ejection fraction of 30%. Which of the following medications, when added to his preadmission regimen, would be most likely to decrease his risk of subsequent mortality?

A 64-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with flank pain and fever. She noted dysuria for the past 3 days. Blood and urine cultures are obtained, and she is started on intravenous ciprofloxacin. Six hours after admission, she becomes tachycardic and her blood pressure drops. Her intravenous fluid is normal saline (NS) at 100 mL/h. Her current blood pressure is 78/40 mm Hg, heart rate is 128/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, and temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F). She seems drowsy yet uncomfortable. Extremities are warm with trace edema. What is the best next course of action?

options.label: B
options.text: Begin norepinephrine infusion and titrate to mean arterial pressure greater than 65 mm Hg.

options.label: C
options.text: Add vancomycin to her antibiotic regimen for improved gram-positive coverage.

questions.correct_answer: D. Administer a bolus of NS.

questions.text: An 84-year-old woman presents to the ED with shortness of breath. She has been coughing for the past 2 to 3 days. On examination heart rate of 102/min, respiratory rate of 24/min, blood pressure 142/58 mm Hg, and temperature of 37.8°C (100°F) with a weight of 52 kg. Oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Upon examination, she appears to be in respiratory distress and disoriented. Chest auscultation reveals few crackles in the left upper lung field. WBC count is 12,500/mm3, BUN is 30 mg/dL, and creatinine is 1.3 mg/dL. A chest radiograph shows an infiltrate in the left upper lung lobe. What is the best initial course of therapy for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Begin a third-generation cephalosporin and admit her to the hospital.

options.label: B
options.text: Begin a third-generation cephalosporin and a macrolide, and admit her to the hospital.

options.label: C
options.text: Begin a respiratory fluoroquinolone and discharge her home with outpatient follow-up.

options.label: D
options.text: Begin bronchodilator therapy with an inhaled beta-agonist.

questions.correct_answer: B. Begin a third-generation cephalosporin and a macrolide, and admit her to the hospital.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute onset of bright red blood per rectum. Symptoms started 2 hours earlier, and he has had three bowel movements since then with copious amounts of blood. He denies prior episodes of rectal bleeding. He notes dizziness with standing but denies abdominal pain. He has had no vomiting or nausea. A nasogastric lavage is performed and shows no coffee-ground material or blood. Lab evaluation reveals hemoglobin of 10.5 g/dL. What is the most likely source of the bleeding?

A 62-year-old man who was admitted to the hospital with community-acquired pneumonia. His comorbidities include diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease. Blood reports showed potassium of 6.5 mEq/L. You immediately order an ECG (see the following figure). What is the next best step in management of this patient’s hyperkalemia?

A 48-year-old man is admitted to your service after an inhalational chemical exposure. He develops respiratory distress and requires endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation. Which of the following is the best way to decrease his risk of developing ventilator-acquired pneumonia?

options.label: A
options.text: Daily interruption of sedation to assess respiratory status

options.label: B
options.text: Nasopharyngeal rather than oropharyngeal endotracheal intubation

options.label: C
options.text: Institution of protocol to keep bed flat during ventilation

questions.correct_answer: A. Daily interruption of sedation to assess respiratory status

questions.text: You have been following a 72-year-old man admitted to the hospital with pneumonia. On the third day of his hospitalization you are called to the bedside by the nurse because of a heart rate of 150 beats/min. The nurse has already printed an ECG (see the following figure). The patient’s current blood pressure is 118/89. He reports feeling weak and appears anxious but denies chest pain and does not appear to be confused or drowsy. What is the next best step in management of this patient?

A 42-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with pneumonia. On the third day of his hospitalization he becomes agitated and confused. He reports feeling spider crawling on his skin. You note that he has a blood pressure of 172/94 mm Hg, heart rate of 107/min, and temperature of 38°C (100.4°F). With the exception of confusion, agitation, and tremor, the remainder of his physical examination is unchanged from earlier in the day. What is the best initial step in management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Emergent noncontrast CT scan of the brain

questions.correct_answer: C. Emergent administration of intravenous lorazepam

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with a history of depression is brought to the emergency department because of confusion developing over the past several hours. He has been drinking alcohol and taking a number of unknown substances. Past medical history-Depression and anxiety. Medications history- Alprazolam and amitriptyline. On examination- BP: 104/68 mm Hg; Plse: 112 beats/minute; Temperature: 99.8°F; Respiratory rate: 22 breaths/minute. On neurologic examination: stuporous and dilated pupils. Abdomen: decreased bowel sounds. Cardiovascular: tachycardia. Skin: hot, dry, flushed. Which of these is most important to do first?

options.label: C
options.text: Do a urine or blood toxicology screen.

questions.text: In continuation with previous clinical vignette, your consultant came for rounds. He asks you-why not give flumazenil to this patient with altered mental status of unclear etiology,What will be your explanation
questions.correct_answer: B. Acute benzodiazepine withdrawal causes seizures.

questions.text: In continuation with previous clinical vignette, you gave dextrose and thiamine. But there is no improvement in altered mental status. On examination dilated pupils still present. Neurological: lethargic, disoriented Skin: dry, warm. What is the most urgent step?
The patient in previous question continues to be lethargic. ECG is done and shows wide QRS (>120 msec) With this additional information, what is the most urgent step?

A 48-year-old man comes to the emergency department after intentionally trying to end his life by taking a bottle of acetaminophen pills within the last hour. He took 30 tablets of 500-mg each. He is extremely nauseated. He has not vomited yet. Vitals- BP: 110/70 mm Hg; Pulse: 108 beats/minute, Temperature: 98°F; Respiratory rate: 12 breaths/minute. Chest, Heart, Abdomen: normal. Neurological: no focal deficits; normal mental status What is the single most important thing to do first?
In previous clinical vignette what in this patient’s history will you ask as that makes it more likely for him to have liver damage or toxicity?

A 55-year-old man come to the emergency because shortness of breath, headache, and ringing in his ears. He usually takes an aspirin a few times a day for his joint pain. Vitals- BP: 124/82 mm Hg; Pulse: 114 beats/minute; Temperature: 101°F; Respiratory: 24 breaths/minute. Past medical history- Rheumatoid arthritis and Depression. Present Medications: Aspirin, Etanercept and Methotrexate. Cardiovascular: no murmur, no gallops Abdomen: soft, nontender Neurological: confused. Which of the following is the most urgent test?

In continuation with previous clinical vignette, you order tests. Results are-Reports: Salicylate level: 70 μg/mL (markedly elevated), Acetaminophen level: none detected. ABG: pH 7.36; partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2 ) 22 mm Hg; partial pressure of oxygen (PO2 ) 68 mm Hg. Serum bicarbonate 18 mEq/L (decreased). LFTs: normal, BUN 22 g/dL (elevated); creatinine 1.9 mg/dL (elevated), Anion gap 20 mmol/L.You made a diagnosis of metabolic acidosis. What is the mechanism of the metabolic acidosis here?

In continuation with previous clinical vignette, patient was managed conservatively. But on second day of hospitalisation patient developed breathlessness and hypoxia. Chest x ray shows bilateral infiltrations. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure was normal. What is the likely cause of this ARDS syndrome.
questions.correct_answer: C. Salicylates cause capillary leak directly.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency after having been found on the floor of his home during a fire. The patient is barely conscious and not able to give clear history. He arrives in the ED within half an hour of being found. Another part of the house was on fire. The neighbours called the police and fire department and they broke down the door. The patient did not sustain burns himself, but several others from the next room sustained significant burn injury. BP: 118/82 mm Hg; Pulse:114 beats/minute Temperature: 98°F; Respiratory rate: 32 breaths/minute.Lab Reports: ABG: pH 7.32; PCO2 28 mm Hg; PO2 90 mm Hg; 98% saturation. COHb level: 42% , ECG: ST depression in V2 to V4.Which parameter represents serious CO poisoning.
questions.correct_answer: B. ST depression on the ECG

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency by his friends because he tried to commit suicide. He drank something in the garage but unable to provide a clear history. There is alcohol like smell from his mouth. On examination- he is disoriented, visibly intoxicated, red eyes, Neurologic: unable to complete the examination because of inability to cooperate, Abdomen: soft, nontender. Cardiovascular and respiratory system are normal. Lab reports: Sodium 140 mEq/L, Glucose 90 mg/dL, Chloride 100 mEq/L, BUN 9 g/dL, Bicarbonate: 16 mEq/L (normal 22–26 mEq/L), Urine Analysis: No white blood cells (WBCs), “envelope-shaped” crystals present. Serum osmolarity 360 mOsm/kg.What is the likely cause

A 50-year-old farmer comes to the ED after a bag of insecticide was accidentally splashed on his face while working on his farm. He developed diarrhea, vomiting, and difficulty breathing. He is spitting continuously since the exposure occurred. There is an increased frequency of urination. He denies fever or cough. On examination- BP: 90/70 mm Hg; Pulse: 54 beats/minute; Temperature: 98°F; Respiratory rate: 36 breaths/minute. Chest: bilateral wheezing, eyes-constricted pupils Cardiovascular: slow heart rate, no murmurs, Abdomen: hyperactive bowel sounds. What is the most important thing to do first?

A 40 year old male,farmer by occupation presented with 5 days history of excessive salivation,visual blurring,loose stools and increased frequency of urination.Since few hours he is complaining of breathing difficulty with wheezing.There is suspected insecticide exposure.On examination pulse is 48/min,BP-100/70,chest examination – ronchi.Before the full assessment and treatment he died.What can be the most common cause of death in this patient

An 85-year-old man comes to the emergency department with 2 days of increasing nausea and vomiting and abdominal pain. The patient has been having visual disturbance and palpitations. His family says he has grown somewhat confused over the last several days. He has past medical history of Atrial fibrillation. His Medications include Chlorthalidone, Digoxin and Nifedipine. On examination- BP: 104/68 mm Hg; Pulse: 75 beats/minute; chest: clear to auscultation bilaterally, Cardiovascular: slow, irregularly irregular rate, Neurological: disoriention. Lab Report: potassium 5.8 mEq/L ; BUN 38 g/dL (elevated); creatinine 2.0 mg/dL, ECG: curved down sloping of ST segments These ECG changes are due to

A 50 year old male presented with lethargy and confusion for 3 days.He is taking digoxin for 5 years in view of dilated cardiomyopathy.Other medications include enalapril,thiazide and carvedilol.He is regular with the medicines.On examination pulse is 50/min,BP-110/70 mmHg,pedal edema present.Chest is clear,CVS-S3 present.neurological examination-patient is disoriented and not able to follow commands properly.ECG shows ‘hockey stick’ sign in almost all leads.Digoxin levels are elevated.What will be most appropriate management

A 55 year old smoker presented with epigastric pain for 6 hours.It is associated with palpitations and unexplained sweating.On examination pulse-64/minute,BP-100/70 mmHg,chest clear,CVS-normal.Troponin is elevated.ECG is done as shown in the figure.What will be culprit coronary vessel if patient has these ECG changes

A 70 year old male with past history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension complaint of chest pain radiating to left arm.On examination pulse-70/min,BP-110/70 mmHg,JVP is raised with positive Kussmaul sign.Lungs are clear on auscultation.CVS-RV S3 present.Troponin is elevated and ECG shows following changes. Which drug shouldn’t be given in this myocardial infarction as shown in this ECG?

A 40 year old male patient comes to emergency department with history of squeezing retrosternal pain for last 2 hours.Pain increased during exertional and associated with sweating and dyspnea.On examination pulse rate 75/min,BP-150/80 mmHg, chest-bilateral breath sounds normal,CVS- normal.ECG is done as shown in the figure.Troponin levels are raised.The following sign as seen in anterior chest wall leads is known as

A 60 year male with long term alcohol intake was started on digoxin as he developed recurrent atrial fibrillation episodes.Patient didn’t turn up for follow up but continued to take digoxin.Now he presented to OPD with intermittent episodes of feeling of skipping a beat and palpitations.You got the ECG done as shown in the figure.On examination- occasional premature beats in pulse appreciated.BP-110/70 mmHg. Which change is not seen in this ECG

A 70-year-old patient known case of dilated cardiomyopathy was started on ACE inhibitors, carvedilol and thiazide. In view of no improvement in symptoms digoxin was added in the treatment regimen. Initially symptoms improved but patient started complaint of palpitations after 2 months.You get the ECG done. What is the diagnosis of these ECG changes

A homeless elderly was brought by police as he was lying on a deserted road with very minimal clothes during peak winter month. On examination his body temperature was 31 C, pulse is 40/min,BP-88/68 mmHg.Chest clear on auscultation.CVS-S1 is soft. Neurological examination-patient is disoriented. You took ECG of the patient. What is/are your observation in the ECG

A 60 year old male comes for his cardiac evaluation.He wants to eliminate the possibility of ischemic heart disease due to his family history.He is a smoker,non-alcoholic and is going through a rough business.He is a known case of aortic stenosis due to bicuspid aortic valve.He also gives h/o suggestive of intermittent claudication.Resting ECG is normal.You are planning for tread mill test. All the following are absolute contraindications for Tread mill test except

A 35 year old male chronic smoker was being evaluated for presence of coronary artery disease. There is no past history of hypertension, dyslipidemia and diabetes. His father died at young age due to ischemic heart disease. You get a resting ECG done which is normal. You plan for tread mill test to diagnose CAD. While doing TMT which of the following is not an indication to stop tread mill exercise test
questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in systolic BP > 20 mmHg
